title: Incisional Hernia
diagnosis_topic: Herniation through a previous surgical incision
setup_script: A 65-year-old obese woman presents with a bulge at her midline laparotomy incision from a hysterectomy performed 5 years ago. The bulge enlarges when she stands and reduces when she lies down.

dynamic_flow.reply: BP 130/75 mmHg, HR 88 bpm, RR 16/min, Temp 36.8 C.
8 cm reducible midline hernia with soft sac; no tenderness or signs of incarceration.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident orders CT scan of the abdomen
dynamic_flow.reply: Fascial defect measuring 5 cm with protrusion of preperitoneal fat; no bowel obstruction.
Obesity, smoking, chronic cough, wound infection and poor nutrition contribute to incisional hernia formation.
Consider open or laparoscopic ventral hernia repair with mesh placement; preoperative weight loss and smoking cessation advised.
Risk of incarceration increases; hernia may enlarge making repair more complex.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If patient has minimal symptoms and significant comorbidities
dynamic_flow.reply: Watchful waiting may be acceptable with education on warning signs.
Open component separation or minimally invasive laparoscopic/robotic repair; choice depends on defect size and surgeon expertise.
Avoid heavy lifting for 6-8 weeks, wear abdominal binder and manage pain.
Recurrence rates lower with mesh; careful closure and tension-free repair improve outcomes.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident discusses prevention in future surgeries
dynamic_flow.reply: Use prophylactic mesh in high-risk patients and optimize perioperative factors like glycemic control.
Recognize signs of strangulation and seek prompt evaluation if pain or incarceration develops.

critical_decision_points: Assessment of incisional hernia size and reducibility via exam and imaging
Risk factor modification prior to elective repair
Decision-making between elective repair and watchful waiting
Selection of operative technique and mesh use
Postoperative care, recurrence prevention and patient education
